#Text=CHAPTER TWO

#Text=For the next half-hour Almayer , who wanted to give Joanna plenty of time , stumbled amongst the lumber in distant parts of his enclosure , sneaked along the fences ; or held his breath , flattened against grass walls behind various outhouses : all this to escape Ali ’s inconveniently zealous search for his master .
#Text=He heard him talk with the head watchman -- sometimes quite close to him in the darkness -- then moving off , coming back , wondering , and , as the time passed , growing uneasy .
#Text=“ He did not fall into the river ?
#Text=-- say , thou blind watcher ! ”
#Text=Ali was growling in a bullying tone , to the other man .
#Text=“ He told me to fetch Mahmat , and when I came back swiftly I found him not in the house .
#Text=There is that Sirani woman there , so that Mahmat cannot steal anything , but it is in my mind , the night will be half gone before I rest . ”
#Text=He shouted --
#Text=“ Master ! O master ! O mast . . . ”
#Text=“ What are you making that noise for ? ” said Almayer , with severity , stepping out close to them .
#Text=The two Malays leaped away from each other in their surprise .
#Text=“ You may go .
#Text=I do n’t want you any more tonight , Ali , ” went on Almayer .
#Text=“ Is Mahmat there ? ”
#Text=“ Unless the ill-behaved savage got tired of waiting .
#Text=Those men know not politeness .
#Text=They should not be spoken to by white men , ” said Ali , resentfully .
#Text=Almayer went towards the house , leaving his servants to wonder where he had sprung from so unexpectedly .
#Text=The watchman hinted obscurely at powers of invisibility possessed by the master , who often at night . . . Ali interrupted him with great scorn .
#Text=Not every white man has the power .
#Text=Now , the Rajah Laut could make himself invisible .
#Text=Also , he could be in two places at once , as everybody knew ; except he -- the useless watchman -- who knew no more about white men than a wild pig ! Ya-wa !
#Text=And Ali strolled towards his hut , yawning loudly .
#Text=As Almayer ascended the steps he heard the noise of a door flung to , and when he entered the verandah he saw only Mahmat there , close to the doorway of the passage .
#Text=Mahmat seemed to be caught in the very act of slinking away , and Almayer noticed that with satisfaction .
#Text=Seeing the white man , the Malay gave up his attempt and leaned against the wall .
#Text=He was a short , thick , broad-shouldered man with very dark skin and a wide , stained , bright-red mouth that uncovered , when he spoke , a close row of black and glistening teeth .
#Text=His eyes were big , prominent , dreamy and restless .
#Text=He said sulkily , looking all over the place from under his eyebrows --
#Text=“ White Tuan , you are great and strong -- and I a poor man .
#Text=Tell me what is your will , and let me go in the name of God .
#Text=It is late . ”
#Text=Almayer examined the man thoughtfully .
#Text=How could he find out whether . . .
#Text=He had it ! Lately he had employed that man and his two brothers as extra boatmen to carry stores , provisions , and new axes to a camp of rattan cutters some distance up the river .
#Text=A three days ’ expedition .
#Text=He would test him now in that way .
#Text=He said negligently --
#Text=“ I want you to start at once for the camp , with surat for the Kavitan .
#Text=One dollar a day . ”
#Text=The man appeared plunged in dull hesitation , but Almayer , who knew his Malays , felt pretty sure from his aspect that nothing would induce the fellow to go .
#Text=He urged --
#Text=“ It is important -- and if you are swift I shall give two dollars for the last day . ”
#Text=“ No , Tuan .
#Text=We do not go , ” said the man , in a hoarse whisper .
#Text=“ Why ? ”
#Text=“ We start on another journey . ”
#Text=“ Where ? ”
#Text=“ To a place we know of , ” said Mahmat , a little louder , in a stubborn manner , and looking at the floor .
#Text=Almayer experienced a feeling of immense joy .
#Text=He said , with affected annoyance --
#Text=“ You men live in my house and it is as if it were your own .
#Text=I may want my house soon . ”
#Text=Mahmat looked up .
#Text=“ We are men of the sea and care not for a roof when we have a canoe that will hold three , and a paddle apiece .
#Text=The sea is our house .
#Text=Peace be with you , Tuan . ”
#Text=He turned and went away rapidly , and Almayer heard him directly afterwards in the courtyard calling to the watchman to open the gate .

#Text=Mahmat passed through the gate in silence , but before the bar had been put up behind him he had made up his mind that if the white man ever wanted to eject him from his hut , he would burn it and also as many of the white man ’s other buildings as he could safely get at .
#Text=And he began to call his brothers before he was inside the dilapidated dwelling .
#Text=“ All ’s well ! ” muttered Almayer to himself , taking some loose Java tobacco from a drawer in the table .
#Text=“ Now if anything comes out I am clear .
#Text=I asked the man to go up the river .
#Text=I urged him .
#Text=He will say so himself .
#Text=Good . ”
#Text=He began to charge the china bowl of his pipe , a pipe with a long cherry stem and a curved mouthpiece , pressing the tobacco down with his thumb and thinking : No.
#Text=I sha’ n’t see her again .
#Text=Do n’t want to .
#Text=I will give her a good start , then go in chase -- and send an express boat after father . Yes ! that ’s it .
